question: [File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Panic vulnerability] Can an attacker craft a malicious WriteTableItem with null table_item.data field to trigger the unwrap() panic on line 78, causing indexer crash and potential loss of liveness for token data indexing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Error propagation] Does the anyhow::Result error handling properly sanitize error messages, or can attackers inject malicious data that leaks sensitive information through error context when TokenWriteSet::from_table_item_type() fails? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Partial failure] When from_table_item_type() returns Ok(None) for the key but valid data for value (or vice versa), does the function correctly handle this inconsistent state, or can it lead to silent data loss and state corruption in the indexer database? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Warning bypass] On lines 160-165, when token_data_id is None, only a warning is logged but processing continues - can an attacker exploit this to bypass token data validation and inject invalid token records into the database? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Pattern matching] In the nested pattern matching (lines 80-97), can an attacker craft table items with mismatched key/value types that pass initial validation but create inconsistent TokenData/CurrentTokenData pairs? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Integer overflow] Can an attacker create tokens with maximum BigDecimal values that cause arithmetic overflow when cloned into both TokenData (line 113) and CurrentTokenData (line 141), leading to database constraint violations or incorrect token accounting? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Supply manipulation] Does the indexer validate that supply (line 28, 114) never exceeds maximum (line 27, 113), or can malicious Move contracts create tokens where supply > maximum, violating token economics and potentially enabling unlimited minting? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Negative values] Can an attacker exploit BigDecimal to inject negative values for maximum, supply, or largest_property_version fields (lines 27-29, 113-115), causing incorrect token accounting or database integrity violations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Precision loss] When BigDecimal values are cloned (lines 113-115, 121-124, 141-143, 146-147), can precision loss occur for very large token supplies, leading to incorrect token balances and potential fund loss? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: CurrentTokenData] [Supply inconsistency] If multiple transactions update the same token's supply concurrently, can race conditions in database updates cause CurrentTokenData.supply (line 54) to diverge from the actual on-chain state, enabling double-spending detection bypasses? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Division by zero] Can an attacker create tokens with royalty_points_denominator set to zero (line 33, 124), causing division-by-zero errors during royalty calculation in downstream systems and potential DoS of NFT marketplaces? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Royalty overflow] Can royalty_points_numerator (line 32, 121) exceed royalty_points_denominator (line 33, 124), allowing creators to set >100% royalties that drain buyer funds and violate economic invariants? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Negative royalties] Are negative BigDecimal values validated for royalty_points_numerator and royalty_points_denominator (lines 32-33, 58-59), or can attackers inject negative royalties causing incorrect payment calculations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Payee validation] Does standardize_address() on line 117 properly validate the payee_address from token_data.royalty, or can invalid addresses be stored allowing royalty payments to be lost or stolen? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: CurrentTokenData] [Royalty mutability] When royalty_mutable is true (line 65), can attackers exploit race conditions between reading current royalties and processing transfers to front-run royalty changes and avoid payment? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Address collision] Does standardize_address() on line 109 (creator) and line 117 (payee) properly handle all address formats, or can attackers craft addresses with identical standardized forms causing hash collisions and token ownership confusion? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Address validation] Can standardize_address() on lines 109, 117, 138, 145 accept malformed addresses shorter than expected, leading to database corruption when addresses are truncated or padded incorrectly? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Creator impersonation] If standardize_address() fails to validate the creator_address (line 109), can an attacker impersonate another creator by manipulating address encoding, stealing attribution and potential royalties? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Case sensitivity] Does address standardization handle case-sensitivity correctly, or can attackers create duplicate token_data_id_hash values (line 100) by varying address case, causing primary key conflicts? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Hash collision] Can an attacker craft multiple distinct TokenDataId objects that produce identical token_data_id_hash values (line 100), allowing them to overwrite existing token metadata and steal token identity? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Collection hash collision] Does get_collection_data_id_hash() on line 99 use a collision-resistant hash, or can attackers create multiple collections with identical collection_data_id_hash values causing metadata confusion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: TokenData] [Primary key collision] Since token_data_id_hash and transaction_version form the primary key (line 19), can an attacker exploit hash collisions to create conflicting database entries that violate uniqueness constraints? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Struct: CurrentTokenData] [Uniqueness violation] With only token_data_id_hash as primary key (line 46), can hash collisions between different tokens cause the indexer to overwrite unrelated token data, leading to permanent data loss? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Hash preimage attack] Can an attacker reverse-engineer the hash function used in token_data_id.to_hash() (line 100) to create controlled collisions that target specific existing tokens? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/models/token_models/token_datas.rs] [Function: from_write_table_item()] [Name truncation] Does get_name_trunc() on line 102 safely truncate token names to NAME_LENGTH (128 chars), or can UTF-8 multibyte characters be split mid-character causing database encoding errors or data corruption? (High)
